Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Detecting Abnormalities in Images

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer interpretation of images has taken huge strides in recent years, but even the most modern algorithms can't come close to matching human capabilities on simple visual tasks. For example, in a brief glance at an image, people reflexively classify the objects in it in terms of the categories they belong to--people, animals, tools, and other significant classes. This allows us to understand the objects' meaning in the image, for example understanding that a scene with many pieces of food might be a dinner table. Because even modern computer vision systems can't make such a classification, they can't automatically detect when an object in a scene doesn't belong, that is, when it is abnormal relative to the categories present in the scene. Detecting such "oddball" or atypical objects is essential to understanding visual scenes, because objects that don't belong are often the ones that play the most important role and require immediate action (like a cat on the dinner table). Studies of human subjects have shown that humans are indeed especially adept at detecting atypical items, which often draw our visual attention even before we become consciously aware of them.

This project aims at developing algorithmic techniques to endow computer visions systems with the same ability. By adapting modern vision techniques to mimic the way human observers classify visual atypicality, researchers will develop computer systems that can examine an image and automatically detect abnormal objects, as well as identifying the nature of the abnormality and quantifying the degree of abnormality. The project involves a collaboration among researchers at multiple universities and multiple scientific specialties, including both computer vision and human vision. The result will be a new and useful class of computer vision techniques that can be applied to visual image understanding in many contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome:

 The project aims at studying abnormality in images: What are the types of abnormality in images? How does one develop computational methods for detecting abnormalities? How does one correctly categorize abnormal instances? The goal of this project was to develop an intelligent system that should be able to perform the following tasks: 1) Detecting whether an image is abnormal; 2) Recognizing the class of object despite abnormality; 3) Identifying the reason for abnormality; and 4) Quantifying the abnormality: defining a metric for abnormality is essential for many applications.

 

Major Activities and Findings:

 - Taxonomy of Abnormality: Based on the data we collected in the first two years of the project, and on the human subjects’ surveys on the data, we have been working on establishing a taxonomy of abnormality. We started at the coarse level. The taxonomy contains three main categories: Object-centric typicality, context abnormality, and scene-centric abnormality. We are further developing the taxonomy at the object-centric branch into four categories.

 - Develop a computational model for reasoning about abnormality: Based on the coarse taxonomy we proposed, we continued our effort to develop computational models of abnormality. The model can predict three types of abnormality scores for a given image: Object-centric typicality, context abnormality, and scene-centric abnormality. We enhanced the models that we developed in the previous year. For the context-specific model, we studied the effect of object location and relative size on abnormality. For the scene-specific model, we studied models for scene attributes and grouping of scene categories that enable reasoning about scene abnormality. For details about the model, see the attached report.

 - We submitted a paper about the taxonomy and the computational model to AAAI’16. The paper was accepted and won the outstanding student paper award

 This exploratory project produced a publically available datasets and taxonomy for studying abnormalities in images. Our research has resulted in 8 published peer reviewed publications. A graduate student was supported in this project and was awarded AAAI2016 outstanding student paper award for this work. Research findings are used in paper reading and discussion in seminar classes. The project opened up collaborations across three universities: CMU, UW, and Rutgers.
